prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We observe dust continuum, CH3CN and CH3(13)CN (J = 14-13) lines for the disk and SiO (J = 6-5) line for the jet. The spatial resolution is set to 0".2, in order to resolve the disk (1"-2"). One 12-m configuration is enough to image the compact jet (~ 2") and disk. The spectral resolution for SiO is set to the coarsest value (~ 1.0 km/s) that is enough to study the kinematics of the jet (dv > 40 km/s). The spectral resolution for the CH3CN and CH3(13)CN lines is set to ~ 0.3 km/s. This is finer than the total line width (~3 km/s) and we will perform further channel smoothing, if signal-to-noise ratios for these lines are not enough. Two basebands only for continuum are in TDM mode. The other two basebands for both line and continuum are in FDM mode. Required sensitivity is determined by the CH3(13)CN line that is weakest (see Table 4). We can detect, at least, seven CH3CN lines (10 - 40 sigma) and four CH3(13)CN lines (5 - 10 sigma). Total continuum bandwidth is 6.1 GHz and the continuum sensitivity is enough (~ 1750 sigma; see Table 3).

We observe dust continuum for the disk, SiO (J = 5-4) for the jet and CO (J = 2-1) line for both the jet and outflow. The spatial resolution is set to 0".2, in order to resolve the disk (1"-2"). We request another science goal for additional 12-m configuration avoiding any resolved-out emission from the extended outflow (~ 6"). The spectral resolution for CO and SiO is set to the coarsest value (~ 1.0 km/s) that is enough to study the kinematics of the jet and outflow (dv > 40 km/s). One baseband only for continuum is in TDM mode. The other three basebands for both line and continuum are in FDM mode. Required sensitivity is determined by the SiO line that is weakest (see Table 4). Total continuum bandwidth is 7.5 GHz and the continuum sensitivity is enough (~ 1137 sigma; see Table 3).

We observe dust continuum for the disk, SiO (J = 5-4) for the jet and CO (J = 2-1) line for both the jet and outflow. The maximum recoverable scale is enough larger than the whole scale of the extended outflow (~ 6"). The spatial resolution of ~ 1".7 is comparable to the past SMA observation. This also allow us to search a large-scale envelope around the disk, that seemed to be resolved-out because of a poor uv-coverage of the past observations. We will combine obtained data with the high-resolution data observed in another science goal. The spectral resolution for CO and SiO is set to the coarsest value (~ 1.0 km/s) that is enough to study the kinematics of the jet and outflow (dv > 40 km/s). One baseband only for continuum is in TDM mode. The other three basebands for both line and continuum are in FDM mode. Only the minimum integration time is enough to detect all the lines and continuum (see Table 3, 4).

We observe dust continuum and C17O (J = 3-2) for the disk, SiO (J = 8-7) for the jet and CO (J = 3-2) line for both the jet and outflow. The spatial resolution is set to 0".2, in order to resolve the disk (1"-2"). We request another science goal for additional 12-m configuration avoiding any resolved-out emission from the extended outflow (~ 6"). The spectral resolution for SiO is set to the coarsest value (~ 1.0 km/s) that is enough to study the kinematics of the jet and outflow (dv > 40 km/s). The spectral resolution for the C17O line is set to ~ 0.4 km/s. This is finer than the total line width (~ 3 km/s) and we will perform further channel smoothing, if signal-to-noise ratios for these lines are not enough. One baseband only for continuum is in TDM mode. The other three basebands for both line and continuum are in FDM mode. Required sensitivity is determined by the SiO line that is weakest (see Table 3). All the lines will be detected with enough signal-to-noise ratio (18 - 48 sigma). Total continuum bandwidth is 6.3 GHz and the continuum sensitivity is enough (~ 1434 sigma; see Table 3).

We observe dust continuum and C17O (J = 3-2) for the disk, SiO (J = 8-7) for the jet and CO (J = 3-2) line for both the jet and outflow. The maximum recoverable scale is enough larger than the whole scale of the extended outflow (~ 6"). This also allow us to search a large-scale envelope around the disk, that seemed to be resolved-out because of a poor uv-coverage of the past observations. The spatial resolution of ~ 1" is still better than the past SMA observation. We will combine obtained data with the high-resolution data observed in another science goal. The spectral resolution for SiO is set to the coarsest value (~ 1.0 km/s) that is enough to study the kinematics of the jet and outflow (dv > 40 km/s). The spectral resolution for the C17O line is set to ~ 0.4 km/s. This is finer than the total line width (~ 3 km/s) and we will perform further channel smoothing, if signal-to-noise ratios for these lines are not enough. One baseband only for continuum is in TDM mode. The other three basebands for both line and continuum are in FDM mode. Only the minimum integration time is enough to detect all the lines and continuum (see Table 3, 4).

We observe dust continuum, C17O (J = 6-5) and CH3CN (J = 37-36) lines for the disk, SiO (J = 16-15) and CO (J = 6-5) lines for the jet. The spatial resolution is set to 0".2, in order to resolve the disk (1"-2"). We request an additional 12-m configuration avoiding any resolve-out of the jet (~ 2"). The spectral resolution for SiO and CO is set to be the coarsest value (~ 1.7 km/s) that is enough to study the kinematics of the jet (dv > 40 km/s). The spectral resolution for the CH3CN and C17O lines is set to ~ 0.4 km/s. This is finer than the total line width (~ 3 km/s) and we will perform further channel smoothing, if signal-to-noise ratios for these lines are not enough. All four basebands for both line and continuum are in FDM mode. Requested sensitivity is determined by the CH3CN lines that are weakest (see Table 4). We can detect, at least, five CH3CN lines (6 - 16 sigma). Total continuum bandwidth is 6.5 GHz and the continuum sensitivity is fully enough (~ 1772 sigma; see Table 3).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a high-resolution imaging of the accretion system around the high mass young stellar object G353.273+0.641. The object has a nearly face-on disk of ~ 1"-2" (1700 - 3400 AU) diameter, accompanied by a pole-on jet. We propose high-resolution (~ 0".2) imaging of the dust continuum and CH3CN lines in band 6, 7 and 9. The main goal is to obtain the first spatially-resolved view of a face-on accretion disk associated with high mass star-formation. We will directly estimate 2D distribution of the surface density and search for any signature of non-axisymmetric structure, such as spiral arms. We will also observe multiple SiO and CO lines simultaneously, investigating the nature of the high mass protostellar jet and how it creates an outflow cavity.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: The Research Institute for Time Studies, Yamaguchi University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research
Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, Chinese Academy of Sciences
